subject: Re: [junit] Beginner's Question
msgSnippet: ... The quickest approach may be to change the scope of those methods from private to protected, and test them that way.  This is assuming, of course, that
messageBody:
> The problem is that each class
> only exposes the constructor and the run() method - so there is
> really not public facing methods to check. The run() goes off on its
> own, doing all kinds of steps using private methods, only ending upon
> death.
> So for example, the Mover thread is checking for files in a given
> directory, if it finds a file it parses information from the filename
> to find its destination, them moves the file to that destination.
> Once it has finished with all of the files it sleeps for a few
> minutes. I would like to check all of parsing steps, but they are
> private only.

The quickest approach may be to change the scope of those methods from
private to protected, and test them that way. This is assuming, of
course, that your test class is in the same package. Its kind of a
hack, but it works.

Generally when I see myself making a lot of protected methods like
this, its a signal that I ought to look at the design. Should your
thread class have these methods as private methods, or would it make
more sense to have a "parser" class that has these operations?

I'm not saying this is definitely the case, but it might be something
to look into. There are a lot of red flags like this when you're
testing, generally summed up as "If its hard to test, it may be hard to
re-use."

Otherwise, you'll have to make up a bunch of test files. I'd suggest
keeping the data for the files in your code, and writing them out to a
temporary directory your code makes rather than having a set of magic
directories.

>
> (2) A second program relies on all of its data in a MS SQL database
> (connection using jdbc). Is there so way to build a fake set of
> tables using junit so that when run under junit it would get data
> from a set of objects instead of actually going to the database. That
> way I can provide for my own data - both bad and good - and track
> those results.

I think Mock objects are exactly what you want here, see
http://www.mockobjects.com/

-Kevin
